title: How to make your writing suspenseful - Victoria Smith

options.label: A
options.text: The fear of monsters and bloodshed

options.label: C
options.text: The fear of death and the supernatural

options.label: D
options.text: The fear of the protagonist's own demise

options.text: Revealing all the answers to the audience

options.label: C

options.text: It builds extra suspense and makes the audience wonder what will happen next

options.text: It makes the story feel predictable

options.label: C
options.text: To make the story feel more predictable

options.label: D
options.text: To add unnecessary complexity to the plot

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum computers can't solve complex problems

title: Why is it so hard to cure cancer? - Kyuson Yun

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason it's difficult to cure cancer?

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer cells are resistant to treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer arises as normal cells accumulate mutations

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer is caused by a virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate number of people affected by cancer at any given time?
What is the name of the brain tumor that can have as many as six different subclones?

options.label: A
options.text: Because lab-grown cells are too complex

options.label: B

options.text: Because lab-grown cells are too simple

options.text: Because lab-grown cells are too expensive

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The cancer would become more aggressive

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer stem cells are the least aggressive type of cancer cell and a single residual cancer stem cell would not seed the growth of a new tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer stem cells are rare cells that seem to have special properties that make them resistant to chemotherapy and radiation

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer stem cells are not a concern

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Developing treatments that are 100% effective 100% of the time

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are trying to survive under stress

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are trying to adapt to their environment and survive under stress

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to mutate and become more aggressive

title: A young inventor's plan to recycle Styrofoam

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial problem that the team wanted to solve?

options.label: A
options.text: How to create a new type of LEGO robot

options.label: C
options.text: How to make a new type of water filter

options.label: D
options.text: How to create a new type of packaging material

multiple-choice.question: What is styrofoam, and why is it considered a non-renewable material?

options.label: A
options.text: Styrofoam is a type of plastic that is biodegradable and can be easily recycled.

options.label: B
options.text: Styrofoam is a type of plastic that is not biodegradable and cannot be easily recycled due to its high production costs and contamination issues.

options.label: C
options.text: Styrofoam is a type of metal that is recyclable and reusable.

options.label: D
options.text: Styrofoam is a type of wood that is biodegradable and compostable.

multiple-choice.question: What is activated carbon, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: Activated carbon is a type of plastic that is used for insulation, and its purpose is to keep things cool.

options.label: B
options.text: Activated carbon is a type of material that is used for water filtration, and its purpose is to remove impurities from water.

options.label: C
options.text: Activated carbon is a type of metal that is used for packaging, and its purpose is to keep things safe.

options.label: D
options.text: Activated carbon is a type of wood that is used for fuel, and its purpose is to provide energy.

multiple-choice.question: What was the team's goal in creating activated carbon from styrofoam waste?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new type of LEGO robot

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce styrofoam waste by turning it into something useful

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new type of water filter

options.label: D
options.text: To make a new type of packaging material

multiple-choice.question: What was the team's biggest challenge in creating activated carbon from styrofoam waste?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the right materials and equipment

options.label: C
options.text: Overcoming the failure of many initial attempts

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the team's success in creating activated carbon from styrofoam waste?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that styrofoam is biodegradable and can be easily recycled.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that activated carbon can be created from styrofoam waste, reducing the environmental impact of styrofoam.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that the team's project was a failure and should not be attempted again.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that the team's project was a success, but it had no real-world applications.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: To discontinue their project and focus on other initiatives.

options.label: C
options.text: To share their results with the public and encourage others to replicate their experiment.

options.label: D
options.text: To use their results to create a new type of LEGO robot.

multiple-choice.question: What message does the team want to convey to others about their project?

options.label: A
options.text: Don't be afraid to fail, because success is always guaranteed.

options.label: B
options.text: Don't be afraid to try new things, because failure is a necessary step towards success.

options.label: C
options.text: Don't be afraid to give up, because it's better to try and fail than to try and succeed.

options.label: D
options.text: Don't be afraid to quit, because it's better to focus on other things.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall significance of the team's project?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that styrofoam is biodegradable and can be easily recycled.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that activated carbon can be created from styrofoam waste, reducing the environmental impact of styrofoam.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that the team's project was a failure and should not be attempted again.

title: Why Facts Don't Convince People (and what you can do about it)

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why humans often make decisions based on emotions rather than facts?

options.label: A
options.text: The human brain evolved to help us survive and not necessarily to help us be factually accurate.

options.label: C
options.text: Emotions are more persuasive than facts.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are not capable of rational thinking.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when our worldview is challenged?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more open-minded and receptive to new information.

options.label: B
options.text: We react aggressively to information that proves us wrong.

options.label: C
options.text: We become less empathetic to members of other groups.

options.label: D
options.text: We become more confident in our original ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "backfire effect" that happens when people encounter facts that contradict their current beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their original ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less confident in their original ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: They become more open-minded and receptive to new information.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it often hard to have an intelligent political debate?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people are naturally rational and open-minded.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brain is constantly protecting our worldview and sense of identity.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people are not interested in politics.

options.label: D
options.text: Because people are not educated enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem of lack of empathy that the transcript mentions?

options.label: A
options.text: When humans are divided into groups, they instinctively become less empathetic to members of other groups.

options.label: B
options.text: When humans are united in groups, they instinctively become more empathetic to members of other groups.

options.label: C
options.text: When humans are alone, they instinctively become more empathetic to others.

options.label: D
options.text: When humans are in a leadership position, they instinctively become more empathetic to others.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do if you want someone to consider factual information that clashes with their beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Confront them directly and argue your point.

options.label: B
options.text: Look for ways to identify the person as part of your tribe and you as part of theirs.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore their beliefs and try to change their mind through force.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the first step in getting someone to consider factual information that clashes with their beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Admitting that you may be wrong.

options.label: B
options.text: Identifying the person as part of your tribe and you as part of theirs.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignoring their beliefs and trying to change their mind through force.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with fighting ignorance with facts, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an effective way to change people's minds.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a waste of time and energy.

options.label: C
options.text: It can have a "backfire effect" and make people more convinced of their original ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the fluid mosaic in a cell membrane?

options.label: C
options.text: To make all the functions of life possible

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of proteins in the fluid mosaic of a cell membrane?
What is the result of the absence of a cell membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: There would be no bacteria, no parasites, no fungi, no animals, and no us

options.label: B
options.text: There would be only bacteria, no parasites, no fungi, no animals, and no us

options.label: C
options.text: There would be no cells, but there would still be bacteria, parasites, fungi, animals, and us

options.label: D
options.text: There would be no cells, no bacteria, no parasites, no fungi, no animals, and no us
